doc.field: Roman Herzog, the President of Germany, has arrived in Kirgizia for a three-day visit where he was welcomed by President Akayev. Afterwards, President Herzog visited a collective farm near Bishkek, the capital of Kirgizia, in which around 40 German families live. Around 20,000 Germans live in the former Soviet republic. Mr. Herzog will travel on to the Ukraine on Tuesday.
Iran's foreign ministry confirms death sentence for German

Iran's foreign ministry has confirmed that a German man has been sentenced to death for alleged sexual contact with a Muslim woman. The news agency Irna reported that the trial would take its normal course, although they did not report on the exact sentencing. According to the German foreign ministry in Bonn, the 56-year-old man was sentenced to death at the first hearing. The German government has appealed against the severity of the sentence.
SPD's state party conference in North Rhine-Westphalia continues

The SPD in North Rhine-Westphalia is continuing itss state party conference. Items on the agenda include drawing up a list for North Rhine-Westphalia candidates for the Bundestag elections. The top candidate will probably be Secretary General of the SPD, Mr. Muentefering. Mr. Raum, the state premier for North Rhine-Westphalia, was elected as state party chairman with 92.5 percent of the vote.
Schmoldt calls for special program to combat joblessness

Schmoldt, Chairman of the Union for Mining, Chemistry and Energy, has called for a special program to combat joblessness in Eastern Germany. Mr. Schmoldt said in Hannover that the program should be financed with one billion marks from the Bundesbank profits. He continued that the program should concentrate on benefiting young people and the long-term unemployed. He also emphasised that the unemployment figures forecast for January would be a sad record high of almost five million.
Savings Bank Association says crisis in Asia is not yet over

According to the German Savings and Deposit Bank Association, the financial crisis in Asia is not yet over. Mr. Koehler, president of the Association, said on the "Deutschlandfunk" radio station that Western investors were partly responsible for the crisis. He said that too much money had flowed into Asia in too short a time, leaving the economy unable to cope sufficiently with the situation. Mr. Koehler is of the opinion that the crisis in Asia will also have a negative effect on the German economy.
Number of immigrant ethnic Germans drops further

The number of immigrant ethnic Germans in January has fallen again in comparison to last year's figures. According to Mr. Waffenschmidt, the Federal Government's Commissioner for Ethnic Germans, around 10,000 ethnic Germans immigrated to Germany last month. Last year the figure was almost 15,000. More than 90 percent of the immigrants came from states in the former Soviet Union. Mr. Waffenschmidt said that reasons for the fall in numbers include German financial aid to Eastern and South Eastern Europe and the introduction of German language tests. Experience has shown that a third of the so-called ethnic Germans from Russia and Kazachstan do not have the legally required knowledge of the German language.
ProAsyl: don't deport any more refugees to Algeria

ProAsyl has appealed to federal and state interior ministers not to depart any more refugees to Algeria. Mr. Kaufmann, the spokesman for the refugee aid organisation, said in Frankfurt that many of the refugees could be returning to life-threatening situations. The interior ministers intend to discuss the situation tomorrow.
Protestant Church also criticises Abortion Consultation Certificate

There has also been criticism within the ranks of the Protestant Church regarding the issuing of Abortion Consultation Certificates for pregnant women. Bishop Engelhardt, the state bishop of Baden, said in an interview with "Suedwestfunk" radio station that since the Pope's letter to the Catholic Church there had also been moves within the Protestant Church to find an alternative solution to the issuing of Abortion Consultation Certificates for the authorising of legal abortions. Bishop Engelhardt made it clear, however, that he saw no reason to call for changes to Paragraph 218, the law governing abortion in Germany.
Health insurance schemes to cover cost of dentistry overseas

Health insurance schemes would like to cover members' dentistry costs for treatment overseas. A spokesman for the Federal Association for the AOK (the state health insurance plan) said to the newspaper "Bild am Sonntag" that the idea of covering dentistry costs incurred overseas was attractive to the various state health insurance schemes, as this could lower costs and increase competition. According to the newspaper, politicians from the CDU/CSU and the SPD would be prepared to support the move in parliament.
